I want you to know that we will never forget the sacrifices you and your loved ones have made to battle this pandemic, and that I will continue to fight for you in Congress, funding the programs necessary to keep you in the fight and accelerate our distribution of vaccines.
Consider this note my way, on behalf of the 700,000+ people I represent, of cheering out our window to you.

As the months have passed, it can feel that America‚Äôs collective appreciation for the same work has waned, that the tedious nature of combatting a pandemic has dulled our vigor, or that we are suffering from ‚ÄúCOVID fatigue.‚Äù
At the beginning of this pandemic, we all watched viral videos of people cheering out their windows to health care workers returning home from their long shifts.
So while it may feel that there is no rest for the weary, I want you to know that you are very much appreciated.

Many of you are working long, grinding shifts. Many of you won‚Äôt be able to see loved ones this holiday season. These sacrifices must certainly carry unbearable weight after months of tireless work.

Sadly, we are seeing more cases, more illness, and more deaths.  I know you experience each of these cases personally, and I can only imagine the emotional and professional pressure laid upon you. I also know each of you are making enormous sacrifices at home as well.
We know that we are calling on you to perform heroic acts, day in and day out.

You all have been working tirelessly for more than 9 months. And while the rest of us enjoyed the beautiful summer, you have been preparing for the surge we now face. Please know we see and we appreciate all you have done and all that we are asking of you now.

To the Drs, RNs, techs and others caring for patients; to the hospital admins, custodians, administrative assistants, and all who make that care possible; I want to convey to each of you my own, and our entire community‚Äôs, immense gratitude for your selfless work.
So in that spirit, let me also extend a heartfelt thanks for your dedication and sacrifice as we battle this pandemic.
Though this year will be unlike any other, we must not lose sight of the deeper meaning of the holiday.

It worked. Eventually, everyone got back to eating and talking‚Äîand Aunt Max was never in charge of bringing the turkey again.

Though Thanksgiving this year isn‚Äôt going the way we‚Äôd planned, we can adapt, smile about Thanksgiving memories, and help each other get through this.

An uproar followed as everyone loudly explained that ‚Äúbring the turkey‚Äù meant a cooked turkey. Aunt Max considered that, then laughed. She said we'd eat Thanksgiving dinner in layers‚Äîa Jell-O course, a potato course, a pie course‚Äîfinishing with a turkey course, in about 6 hours.

They burst through the front door, and Uncle Crowbar banged the heavy roaster on the kitchen countertop as people crowded around to see the turkey. With a flourish, Aunt Max lifted the lid, proclaiming, ‚ÄúBiggest Turkey Ever!‚Äù

Everyone jumped back. It was RAW.

My mother fretted and Aunt Alice fumed. The boys buzzed around trying to get a spoonful of this or a crust of that. Aunt Bee tried to keep everything in order. Still no Aunt Max. Then one of the boys spotted her coming up the walk with Uncle Crowbar (that name is another story).

Thanksgiving dinner was set for noon, and most of the family was there by mid-morning. The table was set. The sweet potato casseroles were out of the oven. The pies were on display. The Jell-O molds were out on special plates. Food was piled everywhere. But no Aunt Max.

Aunt Max was funny and quick-talking. She never took anything too seriously, including time. And she wasn‚Äôt much of a cook, so the other sisters made sure that she was up to the task‚Äîpeppering her with questions, making sure she'd get a big enough turkey.
